title: Ifeoma Onumonu focuses on staying present during journey to the World Cup with Nigeria
body_text:
In The Journey to the Cup, The Athletic follows six players as they work towards a place in the 2023 Womenâ€™s World Cup. Follow along as we check in with them each month in the build-up to the tournament, tracking their progress as they prepare both mentally and physically for a chance to shine on the gameâ€™s biggest stage.
Advertisement
Trusting the process is the attitude Nigeriaâ€™s head coach Randy Waldrum is trying to instill in the team throughout his tenure.
Recently, that process included a seven-game losing streak, dating back to July 2022 when Nigeria lost on penalties to Morocco in the semifinal of Womenâ€™s Africa Cup of Nations. For the Super Falcons, trust meant letting go of their quest to win a 10th WAFCON title and looking towards the bigger picture: a successful campaign at the Womenâ€™s World Cup in July, starting with the 2023 Womenâ€™s Revelations Cup in LeÃ³n, Mexico.
Coming off two narrow 1-0 losses to Mexico and Colombia, Nigeria snapped its losing streak with a win against Costa Rica. Forward Ifeoma Onumonu started all three matches and played 238 minutes as the teamâ€™s center forward.
Onumonu is trusting the process and staying present
She said itâ€™s easy to get caught up in the results, but Nigeria has to understand the games leading up to the World Cup are part of a journey.
â€œ(Weâ€™re) trying to stay focused and dialed into what weâ€™re trying to build,â€ Onumonu told The Athletic. â€œI think everyone goes out to win the game. But ultimately, this is a team sport so â€¦ you can try to go out there and get the game yourself, but itâ€™s going to take a team effort in order to progress and get to where we want to be by World Cup time.â€
Making the most of each game and camp will be crucial to Nigeriaâ€™s goal of advancing out of a tough group B and reaching the knockout stage of the tournament â€“ something the Super Falcons have only done twice in their history, making the quarterfinals in 1999 when the tournament only had 16 teams and the round of 16 in 2019. No African team has made it to the semifinals of the tournament in its 32-year history.
With only 142 days until the first match of the World Cup, the opportunities to call Nigeriaâ€™s squad into camp are limited to two more international windows â€“ one in April and one in June/July before the tournament.
Advertisement
The 23 players will come from different playing styles and leagues around the world. One thing Onumonu concentrated on during the February window was creating on-field chemistry with her teammates. Frustrations can and do arise from a squad that doesnâ€™t often play together, but she says the key to overcoming them is learning the strengths of each player and having conversations.
The win over Costa Rica in their final game of the Womenâ€™s Revelations Cup was a result of building team chemistry during the window.
â€œWe played our best against Costa Rica,â€ Onumonu said. â€œI think that came because, over the last nine days prior, it was trying to figure out how to play our best within the system (and) playing in a way we know within this new system that weâ€™re given.â€
Along with building chemistry on the field, Onumonu is still adjusting to the teamâ€™s culture off the field, as she previously told The Athletic.
Growing up in Southern California and American soccer culture, Onumonu experienced an environment more focused on the individual rather than the collective, like her Nigerian-born teammates. Despite the cultural differences, Onumonu says there are always good vibes around the camp and she enjoys singing with the team.

The other key to her game, staying present, is a mentality Onumonu is constantly and consistently working toward developing.
â€œI have to kind of take a step back and realize that it needs to be like a day-to-day and moment-to-moment thing as well,â€ she said.
It also means a change in how Onumonu views competition.
â€œIt sounds crazy, but I feel like we kind of get caught up in that competition,â€ she said, â€œbut in an almost negative way.â€
Advertisement
Instead of trying to make fewer mistakes than her teammates, she is focused on playing to the best of her abilities.
â€œThatâ€™s been like my focus in my way of trying to stay present day to day,â€ Onumonu said.
In February, Onumonu rejoined her NJ/NY Gotham FC teammates in Florida to prepare for the upcoming NWSL season. With a chance to make Nigeriaâ€™s final World Cup roster, Onumonu looks to return to her form from the 2021 season when she was tied for the leagueâ€™s most goal contributions (eight goals and four assists) and earned a spot on the Best XI Second Team.
A new NWSL season on the horizon also means new opportunities for Onumonu to continue her work as a board member of the Black Womenâ€™s Player Collective. Recently the collective gifted four HBCU womenâ€™s soccer teams Therabody equipment to help with recovery work. Onumonu said they chose recovery equipment because HBCUs are often forgotten about and donâ€™t get the same resources as other universities. The initiative has a two-fold impact: to give HBCU student-athletes equipment and to shine a light on programs many people donâ€™t know about.
Though Onumonu is still working on her goals for this year, growing on and off the field with Nigeria, Gotham and BWPC are at the top of her list.
